text: we might want to think about figuring out how to capture all of these steps in readthedocs

attachments.fallback:
[October 24th, 2016 6:44 AM] garisingh: <@U2BF87970>  - I'm back.   So hopefully what we can do here is get you up and running with the Docker images and then developing / running your chaincode on your Windows 7 host.

Step 1:    Install Docker Toolbox for Windows  (I think you did this already)

Step 2:    Use the "Docker QuickStart Terminal"  shortcut (either on your desktop or via the start menu) to launch Docker on your Windows host   (if you've done this already, I'd recommend closing any open "QuickStart Terminal" Windows

Step 3:  After launching the "QuickStart Terminal", you'll see a line printed out underneath the Docker picture - something like `...configured to use the default machine with IP <http://XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX|XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX>`    - you will want to capture that IP address as we'll need it when we run the chaincode later

Step 4:  Follow <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#option-3-docker-toolbox>  to create a compose file and launch the peer and membership services

Step 1:    Install Docker Toolbox for Windows  (I think you did this already)

Step 2:    Use the "Docker QuickStart Terminal"  shortcut (either on your desktop or via the start menu) to launch Docker on your Windows host   (if you've done this already, I'd recommend closing any open "QuickStart Terminal" Windows

Step 3:  After launching the "QuickStart Terminal", you'll see a line printed out underneath the Docker picture - something like `...configured to use the default machine with IP <http://XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX|XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX>`    - you will want to capture that IP address as we'll need it when we run the chaincode later

Step 4:  Follow <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#option-3-docker-toolbox>  to create a compose file and launch the peer and membership services

text: well assuming that someone else tries it and it works  :wink:
<@U0KM61BCP> <@U10LM0FFZ>   - assuming the stuff I wrote in the general channel work for people, seems like we might want to find a way to get it into the docs?
<@U0PB67X4K> - yes for sure.  will handle.  It’s clear that there are some head-on collisions with docker and various OS
